choices.text: Binding to sodium channels and causing their inactivation

questions.text: Mechanism of Action of local anaesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• Local anesthetics bind a specific region of the α subunit and inhibit voltage-gated Sodium channels, preventing channel activation and inhibiting the Na influx associated with membrane depolarization.
• With increasing local anesthetic concentrations, an increasing fraction of the Na channels in the membrane bind a local anesthetic molecule and cannot conduct Na ions as consequence, impulse conduction slows, the rate of rise and the magnitude of the action potential decrease, and the threshold for excitation and impulse conduction increases progressively.
• At high enough local anesthetic concentrations and with a sufficient fraction of local anesthetic-bound Na channels, an action potential can no longer be generated, and impulse propagation is abolished.
• Local anesthetics have a greater affinity for the channel in the open or inactivated state than in the resting state. (AIIMSQ)
• Local anesthetic binding to Na channels does not alter the resting membrane potential. (NEETQ)

questions.text: Shortest acting Muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Important points about action of muscle relaxants:
1: shortest and fastest acting muscle relaxant (overall ): scoline
2: shortest acting NDMR: gantacurium > mivacurium
3: fastest acting NDMR : rocuronium
4: longest acting NDMR: doxacurium

questions.text: Halothane causes malignant hyperthermia by affecting which channels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• Malignant hyperthermia is a hypermetabolic muscle disorder due to genetic mutation in the ryanodine receptor.
• The mutation is seen most commonly in chromosome 19.
• This mutation causes uncontrolled release of calcium from sarcoplasmic reticulum causing intense muscle contractions and subsequent complications of hypermetabolism.

questions.text: A case of head injury with SDH with high intracranial pressure to be going for surgical drainage which anesthesia to be used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with severe ARDS is on mechanical ventilation in the ICU. The intensivist increases the PEEP from 5 cm H₂O to 12 cm H₂O. Which of the following is the most important beneficial effect of applying optimal PEEP in such a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Improves alveolar recruitment and oxygenation

Explanation:
• PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure) is applied in ICU ventilation to maintain alveoli open at the end of expiration.
• Primary beneficial effect: It prevents alveolar collapse, improves functional residual capacity (FRC), and hence improves oxygenation (especially in conditions like ARDS where shunt and atelectasis are major problems).
• Other effects:
o A: PEEP can decrease venous return and preload → but this is a harmful hemodynamic effect, not the intended benefit.
o C: Higher PEEP may increase barotrauma risk → again, a complication, not the main role.
o D: PEEP may increase right ventricular afterload (by raising pulmonary vascular resistance), but this is also a side effect.

choices.text: A larger sized LMA than usual

questions.text: A 54-year-old professional singer presents to the hospital with a peptic perforation and is posted for an emergency exploratory laparotomy He is very worried about endotracheal intubation because of his profession. He requests the use of a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) and does not want to be intubated. What is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• LMAs are frequently used to provide a patent airway during general anesthesia. While most providers prefer to use them for patients who are breathing spontaneously, positive pressure ventilation can be provided with a well seated LMA.
• LMA's do not protect against gastric content aspiration. Aspiration of gastric contents can be fatal.
• The difference between a 1st and 2nd generation LMA is in the cuff material and a separate access hole to the esophagus. They are designed to provide a higher seal pressure allowing for higher positive pressure ventilation.
• In an emergency procedure, an LMA is not a good choice for primary airway management as LMAs do not protect against gastric content aspiration. 
• Endotracheal intubation is a gold standard method of airway access when there is increased risk of aspiration.

choices.text: The anesthesiologist immediately changed the endotracheal tube with a larger tube
The anesthesiologist immediately deepened the plane of anesthesia by a bolus dose of propofol
The anesthesiologist changed the ventilator settings to higher tidal volume
The anesthesiologist informed the surgeon to stop the surgery

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The patient has a past medical history of asthma on regular treatment with last exacerbation a month back. Rest all investigations are normal. Standard induction is done with propofol and fentanyl with vecuronium as muscle relaxant and cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted and confirmed in position using a capnography trace on the monitor. Shortly after the commencement of the surgery, the ventilator suddenly start showing alarm of increased peak airway pressures and the capnography waveform changes to image A. the anaesthesiologist immediately identifies the problem and intervenes and after 10 mins the capnograph changes to image B. which of the following is true about the intervention by the anesthesiologist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Intraoperative bronchospasm
• Bronchospasm is a reversible reflex spasm of the smooth muscle in the bronchi.
• Bronchospasm is vagally mediated and caused by histamine, or one of many noxious stimuli, including cold air, inhaled irritants, and instrumentation (eg, tracheal intubation, surgical stimulation in light planes of anesthesia).
• Bronchospasm is mediated by vagal afferents which result in an increase in cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP).
• It is more common in asthmatics.

Bronchospasm: Manifestations
• Rapidly increasing peak inspiratory pressure (plateau pressure unchanged)
• Wheezing
• Slowly increasing wave on the capnograph (shark fin appearance)
• Decreasing exhaled tidal volumes
Bronchospasm: Acute Treatment
1) Deepen anesthetic – increase volatile anesthetic concentration 
All volatile anesthetic agents are bronchodilators
Propofol or ketamine can be used to deepen the plane as well.
Ketamine has additional Broncho dilating effect
2) Consider alternative causes of high airway pressures eg. kinked tube, endobronchial intubation, etc.
3) Inhaled β2 -agonists – delivered to the inspiratory limb of the circuit through a metered dose inhaler or nebulized. If the severity of bronchospasm prohibits delivery of inhaled beta agonists, consider infusions of IV agonists such as terbutaline or epinephrine.
4) Consider administering intravenous steroids

choices.text: Chest compressions should be delivered at a depth of at least 2.5 cm at a rate of 60–80/min
Allowing complete chest recoil between compressions improves coronary perfusion
Interruptions in chest compressions are acceptable if the rescuer feels fatigued
Chest compressions should be given at a depth of 7–8 cm to maximize cardiac output

questions.text: During cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) in an adult patient with cardiac arrest, which of the following statements regarding chest compressions is most correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Allowing complete chest recoil between compressions improves coronary perfusion

Explanation:
• High-quality CPR is the cornerstone of resuscitation.
• Key components include:
o Compression rate: 100–120/min (not 60–80/min → option A is wrong).
o Compression depth: ~5–6 cm in adults (not shallow 2.5 cm or very deep 7–8 cm → options A and D are incorrect).
o Complete chest recoil: Essential, because it allows venous return and coronary perfusion pressure → this is the correct answer.
o Interruptions: Should be minimized (<10 sec) since interruptions reduce perfusion and survival → option C is wrong.

questions.text: A patient is experiencing a symptomatic new wide complex QRS rhythm that is unstable. Cardioversion is indicated. He has a high ASA risk score (unstable uncontrolled ischemic heart disease and diabetes) with a Mallampati score of 2. What is the most appropriate induction agent for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• Etomidate is frequently used for cardiac procedural sedation because it has limited effect on vital signs; there is essentially no cardiac stimulation or suppression.
• Ketamine may raise heart rate and blood pressure. In the setting of a patient whose cardiac status is tenuous, elevating the heart rate may increase myocardial oxygen demand and thereby increase ischemia. 
• Fentanyl, used alone, has good analgesic properties via a central mechanism (blunting frontal lobe function) but, in doses sufficient to make painful procedures tolerable, may suppress respirations. 
• Propofol has a good analgesic and hypnotic properties, it drops peripheral vascular resistance and thus may cause a hypotension. This may compromise cardiac circulation, thus increasing ischemia and decreasing cardiac output.

questions.text: There is a sick patient in ward who needs supplemental oxygen. It will be given from which of the following cylinder?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic agent is best for cardiac patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• Isoflurane causes least decrease in cardiac output and maximum decrease in systemic vascular resistance.
• It is best agent to be used for cardiac patients.

questions.text:
What are the components of high-quality CPR?

A. Compression rate 100-120/min

B. Depth in adults 5-6cm

C. Ventilation 20-25 breaths/mins

D. Allow recoil
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following structures are not encountered during epidural anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


• As the name is suggestive, epidural anesthesia involves placing a catheter in the epidural space.
• Since it is outside the Dural layer of meninges so it is essentially not pierced in it.
• Layers pierced during epidural catheter placement (from outside to inside)
• Skin>>> subcutaneous tissue>>> supraspinous ligament>>> interspinous ligament>>> ligamentum flavum

choices.text: Risk of difficult bag mask ventilation
Risk of injury to teeth during intubation

questions.text: Modified Mallampatti classification used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• A normal-size tongue allows visualization of certain oropharyngeal structures. As the tongue size increases, some structures become hidden from view.
• Application of the Mallampati classification system is easy and painless. 
• The patient is seated in the neutral position. The mouth is opened as wide as possible, and the tongue is protruded as far as possible. 
• Phonation is discouraged because it raises the soft palate and allows visualization of additional structures.
• The observer looks for specific anatomic landmarks: the faucial pillars, uvula, hard palate, and soft palate.
• This system suggests that as tongue size increases, fewer structures are visualized, and laryngoscopy becomes more difficult

questions.text: Which of the following is a sole high potency inhaled anesthetic agent that can be used for both induction and endotracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Inhalational Induction of Anesthesia

Another option for the induction of general anesthesia is inhalational induction with volatile anesthetic. This technique is commonly used in pediatric anesthesia to provide a painless, needle-free experience for the child. In adults, an inhalational induction of anesthesia is used when IV access is not available or when the specific advantages of the technique are desirable. Advantages of an inhalational induction of anesthesia are the maintenance of spontaneous ventilation and the potential for gradual changes in the depth of anesthesia and associated respiratory and cardiovascular effects. Inhalational induction of anesthesia has also been used for RSI, with a rapid-onset NMBD administered at LOC (also see Chapter 27).

Sevoflurane is currently the most commonly used volatile anesthetic for inhalational induction because of its lack of pungency and low blood:gas solubility, allowing for a smooth induction of anesthesia that can provide suitable conditions for airway management with or without adjuvant drugs such as NMBDs or opioids.

• One main disadvantage of halothane is its high blood:gas partition coefficient, which leads to relatively long induction times. 
• It also can produce cardiac dysrhythmias, myocardial depression, and halothane-induced hepatitis. 
• Because of the inability to achieve deep levels of anesthesia with halothane because of its side effects, the use of NMBDs, opioids, or both, is often required

choices.text: Continue the original pattern of CPR
Increase the depth of sternal depression

questions.text: A 68-year-old man collapses in the middle of a mall. A good Samaritan immediately rushes to help the victim. He assesses the responsiveness and pulse and immediately starts cardiopulmonary resuscitation and calls for help by dialling 911. During cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) he performs external chest compression at the rate of 90/min with 2 inches of sternal depression. The most appropriate action is to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Maximum flow rate of oxygen that can be used by conventional oxygen therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• Conventional oxygen therapy (COT) is the main supportive treatment administered to patients after planned extubation and has conventionally been delivered using nasal prongs, cannula or masks.
• However, the maximal oxygen flow rates that these devices can deliver are limited.
• The maximal oxygen flow rate delivered by COT is only 15 L/min, which is far lower than the demands of post extubation patients with acute respiratory failure.
• Therefore, ambient air dilutes the supplied oxygen, and finally, the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) is significantly reduced in the alveoli.
• Furthermore, with oxygen delivered by COT, it is difficult to meet the requirements of heating and humidification in these patients.

• High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can supply a mixture of air and oxygen via a heated and humidified circuit at a very high flow.
• It can provide almost pure oxygen with a FiO2 of approximately 100% and a maximal flow rate up to 60 L/min.
• The use of a HFNC may generate a positive airway pressure, ameliorate oxygenation and dyspnoea, reduce the respiratory rate and work of breathing, and improve comfort

questions.text: A 44-year-old man, brought to the emergency room after a car accident, required intubation and mechanical ventilation. Patient history was significant for a genetically deficient plasma cholinesterase. A muscle relaxant was administered IV. Which of the following muscle relaxants would be contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• Mivacurium and succinylcholine are two neuromuscular blockers metabolized by plasma cholinesterase. 
• In patients with a genetically induced deficiency of the normal plasma
cholinesterase these drugs can cause apnea of several hours and are therefore contraindicated.

questions.text: What is the frequency of stimulus in tetanic stimulation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is scheduled for an appendectomy. The patient is administered glycopyrrolate along with other routine drugs just before intubating the patient. Which of the following side effects is expected intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• Glycopyrrolate is a muscarinic anticholinergic agent. 
• It is used to reduce salivary secretions before surgery. 
• A blockade of reflexive vagal cardiac inhibition reflexes during both intubation and anesthetic induction occurs during glycopyrrolate use. 
• The intravenous formulation of glycopyrrolate is classically used to reverse vagal reflexes and bradycardia intraoperatively.
• Glycopyrrolate may be administered to reverse the neuromuscular blockade due to nondepolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively and is frequently used in conjunction with neostigmine, a cholinesterase inhibitor. 
• It is also used to reduce severe or chronic drooling in pediatric patients with neurologic conditions, such as cerebral palsy.
• Glycopyrrolate does not cause chest pain or bradycardia.

questions.text: A patient underwent cardiovascular collapse following a regional anesthetic block with bupivacaine, what would be the immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST):
• When blood concentration of local anesthetic agent reaches beyond a certain limit then it causes systemic toxicity called as LAST.
Etiology:
1: excessive \ toxic dose of local anesthetic agent given.
2: accidental intravascular placement of the local anesthetic while giving a regional block.

There are 2 forms of LAST:
1: central nervous system toxicity: early and mild 
2: cardiovascular system toxicity: late and grave

Most cardiotoxic LA is Bupivacaine,
Treatment of choice for bupivacaine induced cardiotoxicity is 20% INTRALIPID solution which increases the rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels from the cardiac myocytes.

choices.text: A persistently low end-tidal CO₂ (<10 mmHg) after 20 minutes of CPR is associated with poor prognosis
A sudden fall in end-tidal CO₂ is an early indicator of return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC)
Capnography cannot differentiate between esophageal and tracheal intubation
End-tidal CO₂ values during CPR are unreliable and should not guide resuscitation

questions.text: During resuscitation of a patient in cardiac arrest, capnography is used to monitor CPR effectiveness. Which of the following statements is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A persistently low end-tidal CO₂ (<10 mmHg) after 20 minutes of CPR is associated with poor prognosis

Explanation:
• Capnography (ETCO₂ monitoring) is an essential tool during anesthesia and critical care.
• In CPR:
o ETCO₂ correlates with cardiac output generated by chest compressions.
o Low ETCO₂ (<10 mmHg) after prolonged CPR predicts very poor survival → hence used as a prognostic marker. 
o Sudden rise in ETCO₂ (not fall) is an early sign of ROSC → option B is wrong.
o Capnography does differentiate esophageal vs. tracheal intubation (flat line in esophageal tube) → option C is wrong.
o ETCO₂ is reliable in guiding CPR quality → option D is wrong.

questions.text: Identify the reading:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• capnography is a measure of End Tidal CO2 concentration in mmhg along with its graphical representation.
• Capnography is one of the essential monitors during anesthesia esp general anesthesia and is an indicator of both respiration and circulation during anesthesia.

choices.text: Spontaneous breathing under the effect of muscle relaxation

questions.text: Identify the capnogram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• This is a typical capnogram of 1st spontaneous breath under the effect of muscle relaxation.
• There is a notch \ dip in the expiratory plateau phase of the capnogram called as curare notch \ cleft.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Anesthetic gas with maximum respiratory irritation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
• Sweet smelling inhaled anesthetic agents: sevoflurane & halothane
• Pungent smelling inhaled agents: isoflurane, desflurane, enflurane
• Odorless inhaled agent: nitrous oxide

choices.text: Ask for a large plastic adhesive, cut a hole into it and place over the patient's mouth to make a seal
Rush to tracheostomy as mask ventilation is failing
Attempt to find a larger mask to make a better seal
Place a second-generation laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of obesity is undergoing an elective herniorrhaphy. Anesthesia is successfully induced. Right after giving a muscle relaxant multiple attempts at direct laryngoscopy failed to visualize the vocal cord.  His oxygen saturation of the patient begins to fall. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

• After induction of anesthesia, including a muscle relaxant, maintaining pre-oxygenation and some ventilation is of paramount importance to avoid hypoxia. 
• Especially in larger individuals, redundant tissue may make positive pressure ventilation difficult. 
• Once the face mask fails to provide an adequate seal, an LMA is a good choice to provide a seal further down the airway.
• The LMA is designed to create a seal around the larynx to allow positive pressure ventilation up to a certain pressure, which can vary between patients and the design of the LMA. 
• Once the patient's saturation begins to fall, swift and decisive action such as inserting an LMA will help to prevent further hypoxia.
• In addition to bypassing facial features, missing teeth, and full beards, LMAs can also be useful to slide past redundant pharyngeal tissues which might obstruct the upper airway.
• LMA's have different designs and features, such as silicone cuffs, gastric access ports, non-inflatable gel cuffs. 
• 2nd generation LMAs often provide higher seal pressure to allow for higher positive pressure ventilation pressures and are preferred in a rescue situation. 
• LMA's, preferably 2nd generation, should be immediately available during induction of anesthesia if airway rescue becomes necessary.

questions.text: Which if the following is the correct sequence of potency of anesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• POTENCY:
• It is defined as the minimum alveolar concentration of anesthetic at 1 atmosphere (atm), which produces immobility in 50% of subjects exposed to a noxious stimulus, usually a skin incision.

questions.text: Which of the inhalational anesthetic uses special vaporizer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

• Desflurane has special physical properties.
• It has a very high vapour pressure ( 660 mmhg) and a very low boiling point ( 23.5 deg Celsius)
• Due to this, it cant be delivered precisely using a conventional vaporizer and so we use a special vaporizer for delivering desflurane called as TEC 6 vaporizer.

choices.text: Less potent and so less laudonosine production

questions.text: Cisatracurium is preferred over atracurium because?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• Cisatracurium is a pure cis isomer of atracurium
• It has similar onset and duration of action as atracurium
• Some differences between the two are:
1: Cisatracurium is metabolized purely by hoffman’s elimination
2: Cisatracurium is 4 times more potent than atracurium
3: there is almost no production of laudonosine because of high potency 
4: Cisatracurium doesn’t cause histamine release.

questions.text: Best circuit for Spontaneous respiration is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following can be used as Induction agent except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
INDUCTION AGENTS: 
• Agents that cause rapid loss of consciousness are the ones that are used as induction agents.
• Most common induction agents are IV induction agents which are
• Thiopentone
• Propofol
• Etomidate
• Ketamine
• Midazolam (rare use)

Inhaled anesthetic agents can also be used for induction but only ones with fast onset of action and sweet smell can be used.
Eg : sevoflurane and halothane

questions.text: The mask shown below was used in Covid 19 patients. Identify:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

OXYGEN DELIVERY SYSTEMS
Oxygen delivery systems are classified as
• low-flow systems: nasal prongs
• reservoir systems: face masks and face masks with reservoir bags
• high flow systems: air-entrainment masks or heated, humidified O2 delivered through nasal prongs

questions.text: A patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes, who is to undergo a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, will be classified as an
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ASA III is a patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life
(functionality incapacitated).

questions.text: Neuromuscular monitoring most commonly done with which nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 
NEURO MUSCULAR MONITORING: uses
• Improve the quality of intubation and reduce airway injury.
• Assess depth of block during surgery
• Identify the residual neuromuscular block 

PERIPHERAL NERVE STIMULATION

To test the function of the neuromuscular junction, a peripheral nerve is stimulated electrically, and the response of the muscle is assessed.

Most common nerve and muscle combination used:
1: ulnar nerve and adductor pollicis muscle
2: 2nd most common used: facial nerve and orbicularis oculi muscle

Different methods of recording of response of the muscle:
1: electro myography
2: mechano myography ( gold standard)
3: accelero myography ( most commonly used)

Patterns of stimulation used:
1: single twitch
2: train of four
3: tetany
4: double burst stimulation

choices.text: Perform a blind finger sweep to remove the food particle

questions.text: Man was eating food at a restaurant and suddenly started choking and became unresponsive, what will be the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CHOKING IN ADULTS ( > 1 YEAR OLD)
• Choking is a preventable cause of death that occurs when food or another object gets stuck in the throat.
• The airway gets blocked and immediate action is needed.
• The person typically only has a few minutes before they pass out.
• The universal sign of choking is holding the neck with one or both hands.

choices.text: On the table hair removal by razor

questions.text: Before Laparoscopic surgery, what advise should be given to the patient by surgeon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• ASA fasting guidelines for elective surgical cases are based on the type of food taken by the patient before surgery and not just in terms of number of hours.
• On table hair removal should be done by a clipper preferably and not a razor as use of razor is associated with increased risk of ssi.

questions.text: Best marker to know whether ET tube is in correct position: -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Confirmation of placement of tube:
• Tracheal intubation is one of the essential medical procedures. 
• Unrecognised or accidental endobronchial intubation results in hypoventilation and collapse of the non-ventilated lung, barotrauma or pneumothorax in the ventilated lung.
• Unrecognised oesophageal intubation can lead to severe morbidity like hypoxic brain damage. 
• Therefore, verification of correct positioning of endotracheal tube (ETT) is essential to avoid serious consequences.

Various methods have been described to identify the correct position of ETT like:
• intubation under direct vision
• inspection of chest wall movements
• auscultation of bilateral breath sounds
• monitoring of end-tidal carbon dioxide (EtCO2)
• use of negative pressure devices
• fibreoptic bronchoscopy
• chest X-ray. 




 Among all, though capnography is considered the most commonly used method, but it may not be reliable under certain conditions, e.g., endobronchial intubation, poor circulatory perfusion as in cardiac arrest, severe hypotension, pulmonary embolism, severe bronchospasm, poor pulmonary reserve like pleural effusion, pneumothorax and pulmonary malignancy.
 Prior bag-mask ventilation leading to gastric insufflation, antacid consumption or ingestion of carbonated beverages also may lead to false positive results with capnography.

questions.text: What manoeuvre is shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Head Tilt/Chin Lift
 The head tilt/chin lift is one of the most common active maneuvers used to open a patient's airway.
 This maneuver should be used only if the clinician is confident that there is no risk of cervical spine injury.
 Standing on the side of the patient, the clinician places one hand on the patient's forehead while simultaneously placing the fingers of the other hand under the patient's mandible.
 The head is then tilted backward while lifting the mandible forward, extending the neck.
 This action creates an open airway by lifting the tongue from the posterior pharynx.
 If effectively applied, the head-tilt/chin-lift maneuver may allow the patient to resume unobstructed breathing without further intervention.
